Award.AwardTitle: Establishing the link between biomolecular dynamics and function from an atomistic perspective

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Regulation of biological processes in the cell relies on physical interactions between biomolecules and on the resulting changes in the dynamics and conformations (shape) of the biomolecules. These processes in turn regulate relocation of biomolecules within different regions of the cell, speed up biochemical reactions, turn on and off gene expression, and aid the correct folding of other proteins. The relationship between three-dimensional structures and function of biomolecules alone is insufficient to fully explain the molecular basis of these processes. Biomolecules are not static but inherently flexible, and the role of biomolecular motions in the regulation of biological functions has remained unclear, despite an increasing number of experimental and theoretical studies. The inability to separate out the contributions of different factors to overall function is at the heart of the problem. The goal of this research project is to establish the molecular basis of the motions of biomolecules involved in biological processes. Computational tools that are developed will be publicly available and implemented into widely used open computational software for anyone to use and improve upon. The research will provide an excellent opportunity to attract and train the next generation of scientists. An advantage of the research is that it cuts across many disciplines, including chemistry, biology, physics, mathematics, and computer science, and, therefore, provides an excellent opportunity to attract students into the sciences and scientific research.

The relationship between structure and function in biomolecules is well established, however, this information is not always adequate to provide a complete understanding of the mechanism of biomolecular processes. The relationship between structure, dynamics and function in allostery and enzyme mechanisms is therefore far from being fully understood. Critical barriers to progress are the lack of fundamental understanding of the role of dynamical motions in biomolecular function and the inability to experimentally describe temporal behaviors of biomolecules at atomic resolution. The goal of this project is to establish the molecular basis of dynamical and allosteric regulation in biological systems involving cooperative substrate binding and transient protein-protein interactions in complex biomolecular assemblies. Specifically, the research uses theory and computer simulations as complementary tools to a variety of experiments, including NMR, X-ray crystallography and Surface Plasmon Resonance, to understand allosteric regulation in a multi-domain enzyme, Pin1, and a transcription factor co-regulator Pirin. The main objectives are to identify dynamical networks of residue-residue interactions that regulate function, to describe their characteristics on a quantitative level, and to explore computational approaches to access long time scale dynamics, overcoming limitations of traditional direct simulation methods. Computational investigation of the above systems in atomic detail will allow understanding of how modulation in dynamics in one region is communicated via a dynamical network of amino acid residues to a spatially distal region. The research will enhance the incorporation of biomolecular dynamics in interpreting experimental results. The research will provide the fundamental knowledge needed to establish the relationship between dynamics, structure, and function in sub-cellular processes.

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods Program in the Division of Chemistry in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The findings of this research have provided the basic understanding of how human proteins work in carrying out important function in cells. When these proteins do not work properly, cells are at risk of not functioning properly that could lead to diseases. The research has produced new computational tools that would assist others in their research and in developing new technology. The research cut across many disciplines, including chemistry, biology, physics, mathematics, and computer science, and provided an excellent opportunity to train students at all levels at Georgia State University. Georgia State University is the largest and most diverse research-intensive university in Georgia, providing a unique opportunity to engage a diverse student body and underrepresented minority groups in science and engineering. 

Proteins, in general, are inherently flexible. The role of this flexibility or dynamics on how proteins function has been the subject of intense debate and, despite an increasing number of experimental and theoretical studies, has remained unclear. Critical barriers to progress had been the lack of fundamental understanding of the role of these dynamical motions in protein function and the lack of adequate microscopic models for interpreting experimental results. The goal of the proposed research was to begin to establish the molecular basis of the dynamical regulation of protein in cellular processes by studying several human proteins using computational simulation as a complementary tool to experiment.

Computer simulations have changed the way we do research and model complex chemical and biochemical systems. Results obtained from the research have implications in structure-based drug design and protein engineering. The findings of the research provided general principles behind protein dynamics and their relevance to protein function. During the funding period, products of the research included twenty-two published papers in well-respected peer-reviewed journals, such as Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, ACS Catalysis, Biochemistry, Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation, Journal of Physical Chemistry B, Journal of Biological Chemistry, and Journal of Chemical Information and Modelling, including an invited review article of the research in Accounts of Chemical Research. These findings have taken the field significantly forward and have open entirely new areas by providing testable hypothesis for experimental research.

The impact of the research has been immediate on the fundamental understanding of the way proteins function and studying proteins. The research has provided immediate feedback to experimentalists, for example. It would have long-term impact on protein engineering and understanding aberrant biological processes in the cell. Results of the research were published and presented at many conferences, scientific meetings, and universities. Computational tools and simulation methods developed as a result of this research have been made publicly available for anyone to use and improve upon. In addition to having impact in the understanding of biological function, the research had an even broader impact on scientific training. The research was tightly integrated with teaching and educational activities. A major component of the endeavors was to engage students at all levels and from diverse backgrounds, especially underrepresented groups, in a way that would entice them to pursue further studies and careers in the sciences. The integrated research, education and training activities would have long lasting societal benefits and would advance the understanding of proteins by establishing fundamental scientific principles. Funding for this research helped trained the next generation of scientists. The funded research resulted in the training of ten undergraduate students, twelve graduate students, six high school and junior college students, and four postdoctoral research associates. The former students have gone on to graduate schools, professional schools, and teaching positions. In addition, K-12 students were exposed to science through a well-established Bio-Bus outreach program at Georgia State University. This outreach program helped to raise scientific literacy among school-aged children and provided access to a larger audience, especially those in school districts with underrepresented minorities in science and engineering.
